notes: This is primarily a structural/computational paper (Julia, dynamic programming). The only regression-type content is a single OLS estimating damage function parameters (Table 1). The specification surface covers only this OLS regression. The broader structural model results (Tables 2-3, A1, A4; Figures 5-8, A1-A2) are not amenable to regression-based specification analysis.

design_audit.notes: Bivariate OLS from Stata `reg log_correct logt`. No FE, no clustering, no controls. Estimates power-law damage function parameters.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Log of climate damage (corrected damage function, D(T) = GDP_loss/(1-GDP_loss))
claim_object.treatment_concept: Log of temperature increase (degrees C above preindustrial)
claim_object.estimand_concept: Power-law exponent d2 in the damage function D(T) = d1 * T^d2, estimated via log-log regression
claim_object.target_population: Meta-analysis sample of climate damage estimates from Howard & Sterner (2017)

constraints.notes: Baseline is bivariate (0 controls). Optional controls from H&S dataset include study quality indicators (Grey, Repeat_Obs, Based_On_Other), damage type indicators (Market, cat), and study design variables (Preindustrial, Year). Max 7 total optional controls.

canonical.notes: Classical (non-robust) OLS standard errors, matching the paper's baseline Stata `reg` command.

budgets.notes: Small dataset (N=43) with limited regression content. Budget is modest.

sampling.notes: 7 optional controls organized into 3 blocks (study_quality, damage_type, study_design). Exhaustive block combinations (2^3-1=7) plus 15 random variable-level subsets.
